physical_examinations.relevant_findings: Neurologic examination showed wide based gait with ataxia worsening after eye closure, upper limb incoordination, gaze-evoked nystagmus, weakness of foot dorsiflexion and toe extension, absent tendon reflexes, dysarthria, and dysphagia for liquids.
physical_examinations.changes_over_time: One month later, during rehabilitation, sudden bilateral loss of visual acuity occurred. Three years later, the neurologic examination showed severe gait ataxia confined to a wheelchair, severe upper limb incoordination with marked action tremor, moderate dysarthria and dysphagia, and moderate weakness of tibialis anterior, extensor hallucis, and dorsal interossei.

physical_examinations.relevant_findings: Bilateral loss of visual acuity, normal VEPs with marked prolongation of P100 wave latency.
Increased protein content in CSF (82 mg/dL) with normal cell count and detection of oligoclonal IgG bands restricted to CSF.

MRI showed multiple T2-hyperintense lesions in the pons, paraventricular region, and corpus callosum, without Gd enhancement. Three years later, MRI showed increased T2 lesion load and one Gd-enhancing lesion in the pons.
physical_examinations.changes_over_time: Increased T2 lesion load and development of Gd-enhancing lesions noted during the three-year follow-up.
